prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript.

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits

Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output: Genes function within context-specific networks to carry out diverse biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can alter their functional roles and, at a broader level, impact disease-relevant biological pathways [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Understanding how genes influence complex traits necessitates a mechanistic comprehension of expression regulation across various cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn can lead to enhanced therapeutic strategies [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have delineated diverse regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the researchâ€™s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.test_description: Has no spelling errors
vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output: Genes function within context-specific networks to carry out various biological processes, and variations in these genes can impact disease-relevant pathways. Understanding how genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of gene expression regulation across different cell types, which is crucial for developing improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements and genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. However, there is still a need to better understand the specific gene expression patterns that underlie disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to address this gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, highlighting the potential for identifying therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities. The novel approach used in this study will provide insights into the clustering of complex traits and contribute to a deeper understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms, ultimately advancing the field of genetic studies and functional genomics.

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the researchâ€™s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Revised paragraph:

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms

vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes. However, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types, which in turn should lead to improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. Despite these advancements, there is still a need for a method that can effectively project genetic associations through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by presenting a novel approach that utilizes gene co-expression and clustering of complex traits to identify therapeutic targets and potential drug repurposing opportunities. The results of this study provide insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms, ultimately contributing to the broader field of genetic studies and functional genomics.

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the researchâ€™s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes. However, determining how genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different cell types, which is crucial for developing improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology when dysregulated. Despite these advancements, there is still a need to project genetic associations through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by presenting a novel method that utilizes gene co-expression and clustering of complex traits to identify therapeutic targets and potential drug repurposing opportunities. The results of this study will provide insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms, ultimately advancing the field of genetic studies and functional genomics.

response.output: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes. Understanding how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types, which should lead to improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. However, there is still a gap in our understanding of how gene expression patterns can be used to project genetic associations, highlight disease etiology, and elucidate drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by presenting a novel method that leverages gene co-expression patterns to project genetic associations, highlight disease etiology, and elucidate drug mechanisms. The results of this study provide insights into potential therapeutic targets and opportunities for drug repurposing, ultimately advancing our understanding of the genetic basis of complex traits and diseases.

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the researchâ€™s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. response.output: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes. However, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types, which in turn should lead to improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. Despite these advancements, there is still a need for a method that can effectively project genetic associations through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by presenting a novel approach that utilizes gene co-expression and clustering of complex traits to identify therapeutic targets and potential drug repurposing opportunities. The results of this study provide insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms, ultimately contributing to the broader field of genetic studies and functional genomics.

outputs.text: Genes function within context-specific networks to carry out various biological processes, and variations in these genes can impact disease-relevant pathways. Understanding how genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of gene expression regulation across different cell types, which is crucial for developing improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements and genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. However, there is still a need to better understand the specific gene expression patterns that underlie disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to address this gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, highlighting the potential for identifying therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities. The novel approach used in this study will provide insights into the clustering of complex traits and contribute to a deeper understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms, ultimately advancing the field of genetic studies and functional genomics.

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

outputs.text: Genes function within context-specific networks to carry out various biological processes, and variations in these genes can impact disease-relevant pathways. Understanding how genes influence complex traits necessitates a mechanistic understanding of gene expression regulation across different cell types, which is crucial for developing improved treatments. Previous studies have described regulatory DNA elements and genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues, but there is still a need to integrate functional genomics data and GWAS data to better identify transcriptional mechanisms that commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. This manuscript aims to address this gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms. By doing so, it aims to provide insights into therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, and the clustering of complex traits, ultimately advancing our understanding of disease etiology and potential treatment strategies.

---
Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes. However, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types, which in turn should lead to improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. Despite these advancements, there is still a need for a method that can effectively project genetic associations through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by presenting a novel approach that utilizes gene co-expression and clustering of complex traits to identify therapeutic targets and potential drug repurposing opportunities. The results of this study provide insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms, ultimately contributing to the broader field of genetic studies and functional genomics.

---
Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes. However, determining how genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different cell types, which is crucial for developing improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology when dysregulated. Despite these advancements, there is still a need to project genetic associations through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by presenting a novel method that utilizes gene co-expression and clustering of complex traits to identify therapeutic targets and potential drug repurposing opportunities. The results of this study will provide insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms, ultimately advancing the field of genetic studies and functional genomics.

It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the researchâ€™s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

---
Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes. Understanding how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types, which should lead to improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. However, there is still a gap in our understanding of how gene expression patterns can be used to project genetic associations, highlight disease etiology, and elucidate drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by presenting a novel method that leverages gene co-expression patterns to project genetic associations, highlight disease etiology, and elucidate drug mechanisms. The results of this study provide insights into potential therapeutic targets and opportunities for drug repurposing, ultimately advancing our understanding of the genetic basis of complex traits and diseases.

---
Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes. Understanding how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types, which should lead to improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. However, there is still a gap in our understanding of how gene expression patterns can be used to project genetic associations, highlight disease etiology, and elucidate drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by presenting a novel method that utilizes gene co-expression patterns to project genetic associations, identify therapeutic targets, and repurpose drugs based on clustering of complex traits. The results of this study provide insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms, moving the field of genetic studies and functional genomics forward.

---
Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes. However, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types, which in turn should lead to improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. Despite these advancements, there is still a need for a method that can effectively project genetic associations through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by presenting a novel approach that utilizes gene co-expression and clustering of complex traits to identify therapeutic targets and potential drug repurposing opportunities. The results of this study provide insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms, ultimately contributing to the broader field of genetic studies and functional genomics.

The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers.
